Stichtingargus.nl w. stichtingargus.nI 12 Do you seiiously declare upon your honor, before these gentlemen, that, unbiased by friends and uninfluenced by nicicenary motives, you ficely and voluntailly offer yourself a candidate for the mysteries of Masonryl (Cdl. ens.) Do you seriously declare, upon your honor, before these gentlemen, that you are prompted to solicit the privileges of Masonry by a favorable opinion conceived of the institution, a desire of knowledge, and a silicere wish of being serviceable to your fellow-creaturesi (Cdl. ens.) Do you seriously declaie, upon your honor, before these gentlemen, that you will cheerfully conform to all the ancieiit established usages and customs of the fraternityl (Cdi. ens } 88—Mr. A. B., the institution of which you are about to beconie a nicmber is one by no means of a light and trifling nature, but of lirgh importance and deep solemnity. Masoniy consists of a coulse of ancient hieroglyphical and moial instructions taught according to ancient usages by types, em - bleins and allegorical figuies, even the ceremony of your gamniiig admission within these walls is emblematical of an event which all must sooner or later experience. It is eniblematic of your final exit from this world to time world to come. You are doubtless aware that whatever a man may possess here on earth, whether it be titles, honors, or eveu his own reputation, will not gain him adinissiom, into the celestial lodge above, but previous to his gaining admission theie he must become poor and penniless, blind and naked, de - pendent on the soveieign will of our Supicmiie Grand Master and, in order to impress these truths more forcibly upon your mind, it is necessary that you r 13 be divested of your outward apparel and clothed in a gaimemit furnished you by the Lodge. Vouchsafe Thine aid, Almighty Father of the Universe, to this our present convention, and grant that this candidate for Masonry may dedicate and devote his life to Thy service and become a true and faithful brother among us. Endue him with a competency of Thy divine wisdom that, by the secrets of our art, he may be better enabled to display the beauties of brotherly love, relief and truth, to the honor of Thy Holy Name. Amen. All- So mt it b.

It is an emblem of innocence and the badge of a Mason; more ancient than the Golden Fleece or Roman Eagle; more honorable than the Star and Garter, or any other order that can be conferred upon you, at this time, or at any future period, by king, prince, potentate or any other person except he be a Mason. THE TWENTY-FOUR INCH OAIJOE is an instrument made use of by operative masons to measure and lay out their work; but we, as Free and Accepted Masons, are taught to make use of it for the more noble and glorious purpose of dividing our time. It being divided into twenty-four equal parts, is emblematical of the twenty-four hours of the day, which we are taught to divide into three equal parts whereby we find eight hours for the service of God and a distressed worthy brother, eight hours for our usual vocations, and eight for refresh - ment and sleep. THE COMMON GAVEL is an instrument made use of by operative masons to break off the corners of rough stones, the better to fit them for the builder’s use; but we, as Free and Accepted Masons, are taught to niake use of it for the more noble and glorious purpose of divesting our minds and consciences of all the vices and superfluities of life, thereby fitting our bodies, as living stones, for that spiritual building, that house not made with hands, eternal in the heavens. 29 CHARGE WM~**~My Brother, as you are now introduced to the first principles of Masonry, I congratulate you on being accepted iiito this ancient and hoiior - able Fraternity. Ancieiit, as having subsisted froni time immeniorial, and honorable as tending, in every particular, so to render al who will be con - formable to its precepts. No institution was ever raised on a better principle or more solid founda - tion; nor were ever mole excellent rules and useful maxims laid down, than are inculcated in the several Masonic lecturcs. The greatest and best of men, in all ages, have been encouragers and promoters of the art, and have liever deemed it derogatory from their dignity to level themselves with the Fraternity, extend their privileges, and patronize then assemblies. There are three great duties which, as a Mason, you are charged to incalcate: to God, your neigh - bor, and yourself. To God, in never memitionmiig His name but with that reverential awe whiiehin is due fom a creature to his Creator, to implore His aid iii all your laudable undertakings, and to es - teem Him as the chief good. To your neighbor, in acting upon the square, and doing unto him as you wish that he should do unto you. And, to vouiself, in avoiding all irregularity and intem - peinace, which may impair yoar faculties, or de - base the dignity of your piofession. A zealous ;ittaeh,nent to these duties will insure public and l)rivate esteem. In the State, you are to be a quiet and peaceful iubject, true to your government and just to your country; you are not to couiitenauce disloyalty or

In your outward demeanor be particularly careful to avoid censn,e or reproach. Let not interest, favor, or prejudice bias your integrity or influence you to be guilty of a dis - honorable action. Although your frequent appearance at our regu - lar meetings is earnestly solicited, yet it is not meant that Masonry should interfere with your necessary Yocations, for these are on no account to be neglected; neither are you to suffer your zeal for the Institution to lead you into argument with those who, through ignorance, may ridicule it. At your leisure hours, that you may improTe in Masonic knowledge, you are to converse with well- informed brethren, who will always be as ready to give, as you will be ready to receive, instruction. Finally, keep sacred and inYiolable the mysteries of the Fraternity, as these are to distinguish you from the rest of the conimunity and mark your consequence among Masons. If, in the circle of your acquaintance, you find a person desirous of being initiated into Masonry, be particularly at - tentive not to recommend him unless you are con - vinced he will conform to our rules, that the honor, glory, and reputation of tIme Institution may be firmly established, and the world at large convinced of its good effects. * (All 1k sts.) THE TWENTY-FOiJE INCH GMJGE is an instrument ninde use of by operative masons to measure and lay out their work; but we, as Free and Accepted \Iasous, are taught to make use of it for the niore Noble and glorious purpose of dividing our time. It being divided into twenty-four equal parts, is emblematical of the twenty-four hours of the day, which we are taught to divide into three equal paits nlieieby we find eight hours for the service of God

FORTITUDE is that noble and steady purpose of the mind whereby we are enabled to undergo any pain, peril, or danger, when prudentially deemed expedient. This virtue is equally distant from rash ness and cowardice and, like the former, should be deeply impressed upon the mind of every Mason, as a safeguard or security against any illegal at - tack that may be made, by force, or otherwise, to extort from him any of those secrets with which he has been so solemnly eiitrusted, and which were emblemat[ca~ly represented upon his first admission into the Lodge whr h ws rcd on -H pnt % a shp ins, at hs n I h, wch aids t -~ Petri. This virtue should be the peculiar charactenstw of every Mason, not only for the government of his conduct while in the lodge, but also when abroad in the world. When the rigor of seasons obliged men to contrive shelter from tie inclemency of the weather we learn that. they first planted tiees on end, and then laid others across to support a coveriiig. The baiids which connected those trees at the top and bottom are said to have given rise to the idea of the base and capital of pillars; and, from this simple hint, originally pro - ceeded the more imp toyed art of archiltecture. The Five Orders are thus classed: The Tuscan, Done, Ionic, Corinthian, aiid Composite. The TUSCAN is the most simple and solid of the five orders. It was invented in Tuscany, whence it derives its name. Its colunin is seven diameteis high; and its capital, base and entablature have but few moldings. The siniphicity of the construc - tion of thus colunmn renders it eligible where orna - ment would be superfluous. The ~ which is plain and natural, is the most ancient and was invented by the Greeks. its column is eight dianieters high, and has seldom any oina meats on base or capital, except moldings, though the frieze is distinguished by triglyphs and muietopes, and tiighyphs compose the ornaments of the fiieze. The solid composition of this order gives it a preference in structumes where stength aid noble siniplicity are chiefly requiied. The Done is the best pioportioned of mull the ordeis. The several parts of which it is composed are founded on the natural position of solid bodies. In its first inven - tion, it was more simple than in its present state. In after-times, when it began to be adorned it gained the annie of Done, for when it was con- 85 Structed in its primitive and simple form, the name of Tuscan was conferred on it. Hence, the Tuscan Illecedes the Done in rank, on account of its re - ~Omblance to that pillar in its original state. The IoNic bears a kind of mean proportion be - ween the more solid and delicate orders. Its column Is nine diameters high; its capital is adorned with volutes, and its cornice has dentils. There is both delicacy and ingenuity displayed in this pillar, the invention of which is attributed to tIme loimians as tIme famous temple of Dana, at Ephesus, was of this order. It is said to have been formed after the mimdel of an agreeable young woman of an elegant shape, dressed in her hair as a comitrast to the Done oider which was formed after that of a strong robust man. The CORiNTHIAN, the richest of the five orders, is ileemed a niasterpiece of art. Its column is ten iiisiiicteis high, nimd its capital is adorned with two rows of leaves and eight vohutes which sustain the milieus. The frieze is oi imnmmieiited with curious de - vices; the cornice wit hi deittils and modilhions. ‘i’hmis order is used in stately and superb structures. It was invented at Coruithm, by Callimachus, who is sd to have taken the hint of thie capital of this p lIar from the following remarkable circumstance: Accidemitahly passing by tIme tomb of a youiig lady lie pemecived a basket of toys covered with a tile, laced over an acanthus root, having been heft theie my her nurse. As the branches grew up they en - iiiimih)iissed thie bashet until, arriving at the tile, they amet with an obstruction and bent downward. The COMPOSITE is compounded of the other orders and was contrived by the Romans. its capital has the two rows of leaves of the Corinthian nad the vohutes of the Ionic. Its column has the qusiter - rounds, as the Tuscan and Done orders; is ten diameters high, and its cornice has dentils or simple modillions. This pillar is generally found in buildings where strength, elegance, and beauty, are displayed. The ancient and original orders of architecture, revered by ~Masons, ale no more than three: the Done, Iomiic and Corinthian, which were invented by the Greeks. To these the Romans have added two: the Tuscan, which they aide plainer thisn time Done, and the Coniposite, which was more omna - mental, if not more beautiful than the Corinthian. The first three or(hers alone, however, show in - vention and particular chaiacter, amid essentially differ from each other. The two others have nothing but what Is borrowed and differ only accidentally. The Tuscan is the Done in its earliest state; and the Coniposite is the Corinth man enriched with the ionic. To the Giechis, themefore, and imot to the Romans we are indebted for what is great, judi - cious, and distinct in aichitecture. FEELING is that sense by which we distinguish time different qualities of bodies, such as heat and cold, hmnidness and softness, roughness and smooth - ness, figure, solidity, amotmon and extension. SNIELLING is that sense by which we distin - guish odors, the vammous kinds of which convey different inipressions to time mind. Animal and vegetable bodies, and indeed most other bodies, ohmile exposed to the air, continually send forth ehhtuvia of vast subtlety, as well in the state of life and growth, as in the state of fermentation and putrefaction. These effluvia, being drawn into the nostrils along with the air, are the means by which all bodies are smelled. Hence, it is evident that there is a manifest appearammee of design in the gient Creator’s having planted tIme organ of smell in the inside of that canal through which the air comitinually passes in respiratioii. TASTING enables us to make a proper distinc - tion in time choice of our food TIme organ of this sense guards time eatmance of the alimentary canal, as that of smellimig guards the entrammee of time canal for respimation. From the situation of both these organs it is plain that they were intended by Nature to distinguish wholesome food from that which is nauseous. Everything that enters into the stomach must undergo the scrutiny of tasting, and by it we are capable of discerning the changes F 89 which the same body undergoes in the different compositions of art, cookery, chemistry, pharmacy, etc. SMELLING and TASTING are inseparably con - miected, and it is by the unnatural kind of life men c’omiimonhy lead ma society, that these senses are rendered less fit to perform their natural offices. On the mind all our knowledge most depends. What, therefore, can be a amore proper subject for time investigation of Mmisons. RHETORIC teaches us to speak copiously and fluently on any subject, not me~e1y with propriety alone, but with all the advantages of force and elegance, wisely contriving to captivate the hearer by strength of argument aild beauty of explesslon, whether it be to entreat and exhort, to admonish or applaud. LOGIC teaches us to guide our reason discretion- ally in the general kno~1edge of things and directs our inquilics after tiuth. It consists of a tegular train of argument, whence we infer, deduce, and conclude, aceording to certain p~cnuses laid down, admitted, or granted; and mn it are employed tbe faculties of conceiving, judging, leasoning, and disposing; all of which ale naturally led oii from one gra(luation ~o another, until the point in ques - tion is finally deterniiiicd. ARITHMETIC teaches the powers and properties of numbers which is variously effected by letters, tables, figures, and instruments. By this art reasons and demonstrations are given for finding out any certain number whose relation, or affinity, to another is already known and discovered. GEOMETRY treats of tbe powers and properties of magnitudes in general where length, breadth, and thickness are considered from a point to a line, from a line to a superficies, and from a superficies to a solid. A point is a dimensionless figure, or an indivisible part of space. A line is a point con- r 91 tinued and a figure of one capacity, namely, length. A superficies is a figure of two dimensions, namely, length and breadth. A solid is a figure of three dimensions, namely, Length, breadth, and thickness. MUSIC teaches the art of forming concords, so as to compose delightful harmony by a mathematical unid proportional arrangement of acute, grave, and ~tIixed sounds. This art, by a series of experiments, Is reduced to a demonstrative science with respect 1:0 tones, and the intervals of sound. It inquires into the nature of concoids and discords, and en - nbles us to find out the proportion between them by numbers. ASTRONOMY is that divine art by which we are twight to read the wisdom, strength and beauty of the Almighty Creator in tbose sacred pages, the celestial hemisphere. Assisted by astronomy, we can observe the motions, measure the distance, Comprehend the magnitudes and calculate the ~criods aiid eclipses of the heavenly bodies. By it we learn the use of tbe globes, the system of the world, and the preliminary law of Nature. While we are employed in the study of this science, we must perceive unparalleled instances of wis - dom and goodness and, through the whole creation, U ace the glorious Author by His works. By OPERAPIVE MASONRY we allude to a proper application of the useful rules of architecture whence a structure will derive figure, strength and beauty, and whence will result a due proportion and a just correspondence in all its parts. It furnishes us with dwellings and convenient shelter from the vicissitudes and inclemencie~ of the seasons, and while it displays the effects of human wisdom, as well in the choice as in the alrangelnent of the sundry materials of which an edifice i scomposed, it demrnistrate~ that a fund o~ science and industry is implanted in n~an for the best, most salutary, and beneficient purposes. ~- vt i mt b spel ~sy. 1 By SPECUL,APIVE MASONR-V, we learn to subdue the passions, act upon the square, keep a tongue of good report, maintain secrecy, and practice Jiai ity. It i~ so far interwoven with religion as to us under obligations to pay that rational homage to the Diety which at once constitutes our (luty and our happiness. It leads the contemplative to view with reverence .ind admiration the glorious works of the creation, .uid inspires him with the most exalted ideas of the perfections of his D]vine Creator. THE GLOBES are two artificial spherical bodies, on the coiivex surfaces of which are represented the countries, seas, a ad various parts of the earth, the face of the heavens, the planetary revolutions, and other particulars. The sphere with the parts of the earth delineated on its surface is called the Terrestial Globe, and that with the constellations and other heavenly bodies, the Celestial Globe. The principal use of the globes, beside serving as maps to distinguish the outward points of the earth and the situation of the fixed stars, is to illustrate and explain the phenoniena arising from the annual revolution and the diurnal rotation of the earth around its own axis. They are the noblest instruments for improving the mind, and giving it the most distinct idea of any problem or proposition, as well as enabling it to solve the same. 109 Contemplating these bodies, we are inspired with a due reveicace for the Deity and His woiks, and mu e induced to encoui age the studies of astrononmy, geography, navigation, and the arts dependent on theni, by which society has been so much beiiefited. They also denote the universality of Masonry. (V ~ - Aft ps + pis, whr dd a ux ai’. ~- At a fit %o wdg sts, cnstg %o th, fv (~ sv sts. To these the Romans have added two: the Tus - can, which they made plainer than the Done, and the Composite, which was more oraaiiiental, if not niore beautiful, than the Coriiithian. The first three orders aloiie, however, show in - vemition and paiticular character, aimd essentially differ from each other. The to o others have noth - ing but what is borrowed amid differ only acci - demitally. The Tuscan is the Done in its earliest state; and the Coniposite is the Corinthian en - riched with the Ionic. To the Greeks, therefore, and not to the Romans, we are indebted for what is great, judicious, and distinct in aichitecture. A point is a dimensionless figure, or an indivisible paint of space. A line is a point continued and a figure of one capacity, namely, length. A superficies is a figure of two dumnensions, namely, length and breadth. A solid is a figure of three dimensions, namely, length, breadth, and thickness. (V@)- (Vt r its advgs. ~ By this science the architect is enabled to con - struct his plans and execute his designs; the general to arrange his soldiers; the engineer to mark out giomimids for encampments; the geographer to give us the dimensions of the world, and all things therein contained; to delineate the extent of seas amid specify the division of empires, kingdoms and piovimices. By it also the astroiiomer is enabled to make his observatuomis and to fix the durations of time and seasons, yeais and cycles. To preserve the repu tation of the Fraternity unsullied must be your constant care and, for this purpose, it is your province to recommend to inferiors, obedience and submission; to your equals, courtesy and affability; to your superiors, kindness and condescension. Universal benevolence you are always to incul - cate and, by the regularity of your own behavior, afford the best ezample for the conduct of others less informed. The Ancient Landmarks, entrusted to your car3, you are carefully to preserve and never suffer them to be infringed, or countenance a devinbon fi-om the established usages and customs of the Fra - ternity. Your virtue, honor, and reputation are concerned in supporting, with dignity, the character you now bear. Let no motive, theiefoie, make you swerve from your duty, violate your vows, or betray your trust; but be true and faithful, and imitate the example of that celebrated artist whom you this evening represented. Nine, eight of which are monitorial: namely, the Pot of Incense, the Beehive, the Book of Con - stitutions guarded by the Tiles’s Sword, the Sword pointing to a Naked Heart, the Anchor and Ark, the Forty-seventh Problem of Euclid, the Hour - Glass, and the Scythe. THE POT OF INCENSE is an emblem of a pure heart which is always an acceptable sacrifice to the Deity and, as this glows with fervent heat, so should our hearts continualy glow with gratitude to the great and beneficent Author of our existence, for the manifold blessings and comforts we enjoy. 179 •iili~ iiesmv~ is an emblem of industry and rec - iiiiiiti(~iids the practice of that virtue to all created Istitigs, from the highest seraph in heaven to the I,,wvst reptile of the dust. It teaches us that, as w4, caine into the world rational and intelLigent Iti’liigs, so we should ever be industrious ones, wvoi- sitting down contented while our fellow - icittures around us are in want, when it is in our jiower to relieve them without inconvenieiice to oil rsclves. When we take a survey of Nature, we view man lii his infancy more helpless and indigent than the brutal creation. He lies languishing for days, itiouths, and years, totally incapable of providing ~iistenance for himseLf, of guarding against the attack of the wild beasts of the field, or sheltering himself from the inclemeiicies of the weather. It might have pleased the great Creator of heaven iind earth to have made man independent of all other beings but, as dependence is one of the ,~ strongest bonds ol~ society, mankind were made de - l]) iiondent on each other for protection and security its they thereby enjoy better opportunities of ful - filling the duties of reciprocal love and friendship. ‘I’lius, was man formed for social and active life, the noblest part of the work of God. And he that will so demean himself as iiot to be endeavoring to idd to the common stock of knowledge and under - standiiig, niny be decmcd a drone in the hive of Nature, a useless meniber of society, and unworthy of our protection as Masons. THE SWORO POINTING TO A NAKED HEART demon - strates that justice will soon or later overtake us and, although our thoughts, words, and actioiis may be hidden from the eyes of man, yet, that All- seeing Eye, whom the sun, moon and stars obey, and under whose watch eul care even comets per - form their stupendous revolutions, prevades the inmost recesses of the human heart, and will re - ward us accoiding to our merits. THE ANCHOR AND ARK arc emblems of a well- grounded hope and a well-spent life. They are cm - blematical of that Divine Ark which safely wafts us over this tempestuous sea of troubles, and that Anchor which shall safely moor us in a peaceful harbor, where the wicked cease from troubling and the weary shall find rest. C THE FORTY-SEVENTH PROBLEM OF EUCLID — this was an invention of our ancient friend and brotlisi-, the great Pythagoras who, in his travels tlimough Asia, Africa and Europe, was initiated into several orders of priesthood, and raised to the subliiiie degree of Master Mason. This wise philosopher enriched his mind abundantly in a general knowl - edge of things, and more especially in geometry, or Masonry. On this subject he drew out many problems and theorems. And, among the most dis - tinguished, he erected this, when, in the joy of his heart, he called Eureka—in the Grecian language signifying ~i I have found it,’’ and upon the dis - covery of which he is said to have sac,,ficcd a 181 hecatomb. It teaches Masons to be general lovers of the arts and sciences. THE HOUR-GLASS [S nfl emblem of human life. Behold! how swiftly the sands run, and how rapidly our lives aic drawing to a close. We cannot, without astoiiisliment, behold the little particles which are coiitained in this machine—how they pass away almost inpeiceptibly aiid yet, to oui suiprise, in the slioit space of an lioni, they ame all exhausted. Thus wastes man 1 Today he puts foith tender leaves of hope; tomoriow blossoiiis, and bears his blushing honors thick upon lain; the next day coiiics a frost wInch nips the shoot, aiid when lie thinks his greatness is still aspiring, he falls, like autuiiin leaves, to ciirich our niotlier earth.
